questions.question: After ……………………… this form, give it to the secretary.
questions.description:
After + ing can be used instead of after + subject + verb. This sentence can also be written as:
After you have completed this form, give it to the secretary.

questions.question: After the movie we had dinner and went to a night club then we ………………………… went home.
questions.description: After all does not mean finally.

questions.question: Give me some soup ……………………
questions.description: We do not normally use also in imperative sentences.

questions.question: ……………………. I don’t like him, I think he is honest.
The shop is open from Monday ………………… Saturday.
questions.description: In American English, either through or to can be used here. In British English, to is preferred.

questions.question: She has bought …………………… car.
questions.description: Another means extra or additional. It is used with singular countable nouns.

questions.question: She is unhappy because she has got ………………….. friends.
questions.description: No means the same as not any, but it is more emphatic.

questions.question: If I were …………………… younger, I would marry you.
questions.description: Any can modify comparatives. This is common after if.

questions.question: What time does the sun ……………………?
questions.description: Rise means get higher or come up.

questions.question: ……………………… must have patience.
questions.description: A singular countable noun must have an article with it. A teacher means any teacher.

questions.question: …………………….. usually start walking at around one year old.
questions.description: We do not use articles with plural and uncountable nouns to talk about people or things in general.

questions.question: There is a cat ……………………. the bed.
questions.description: Under and underneath can both indicate physical position.
